page.title: 19LANDSCAPE AT SANDHEAD
page.content: The most obvious feature of our block is the sea and its beach. One rarely looses sight of it because of the rise of the land away from beach level. A second very prominent feature is an escarpment, which is called " the raised beach " because it is said to have been left as the last Ice Age receeded and the sea level dropped. Once on top of the escarpment the view is of gently rolling grasslands, with the occasional small wood, mainly conifers, planted where the ground is not suitable for cultivation. Trees are obviously planted on the " STEEPY ", as the slope of the escarpment is called, and they shelter the village nestling at its foot. At the south end of the village and high above it, is the school and the Stairmount housing scheme, deriving its name from the steps to be climbed to reach it.
